sum(last_over_time(oracledb_database{alias=~"$alias"}[24h])) by (alias, instance, job, name, log_mode, database_role, platform_name, flashback_on)

ceil(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="Host CPU Usage Per Sec"} / ignoring(metric_name) 
 oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="Host CPU Utilization (%)"})

panels.title: Host CPU Utilization (%)

panels.description: Oracle user% + sys%

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="CPU Usage Per Sec"}[$intv]) / ignoring(metric_name) 
(avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="Host CPU Usage Per Sec"}[$intv]) / ignoring(metric_name) 
 avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="Host CPU Utilization (%)"}[$intv])
)

avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="CPU Usage Per Sec"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)/ ignoring(metric_name) 
(avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="Host CPU Usage Per Sec"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv) / ignoring(metric_name) 
 avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="Host CPU Utilization (%)"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.description:
Logical Reads  = DB Block Gets + Consistent Read Gets
This metric represents the number of logical reads per second.
A logical read is a read request for a data block from the SGA. 
Logical reads may result in a physical read if the requested block does not reside with the buffer cache.
panels.title: Logical Reads (blocks)

panels.description: This metric represents bytes of data read from disk per second.

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="Physical Read Bytes Per Sec"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: Physical Reads (bytes)

panels.description: This statistic represents database bytes written to SGA buffers cached to disk by the DBWR background process and PGA by processes performing direct writes.

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="Physical Write Bytes Per Sec"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: Physical Writes (bytes)

panels.title: Current Logons Count

panels.description:
This metric represents the number of long table scans per second during sample period. 
A table is considered 'long' if the table is not cached and if its high-water mark is greater than 5 blocks.

avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="Long Table Scans Per Sec"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.description: DB Time = CPU Time + Wait Time
panels.title: Wait Events Time

panels.description:
When a user session COMMITs (or rolls back), the sessions redo information needs to be flushed to the redo log file. 
The user session will post the LGWR to write all redo required from the log buffer to the redo log file. 
When the LGWR has finished it will post the user session. 
The user session waits on this wait event while waiting for LGWR to post it back to confirm all redo changes are safely on disk.
panels.title: log file sync - Wait time(s)

panels.description: As the db file parallel write wait event belongs to the Oracle DBWR process, the log file parallel write wait event belongs to the Log Writer (LGWR) process. When it is time to write, the LGWR process writes the redo buffer to the online redo files in parallel and waits on the log file parallel write event until the last I/O is on disk.
panels.title: log file parallel write - W_tm(s)

panels.description: This event shows a wait for a foreground process while doing a sequential read from the database. The I/O is generally issued as a single I/O request to the OS; the wait blocks until the I/O request completes.
panels.title: db file sequential read - W_tm(s)

panels.description: This is the same type of event as "db file sequential read", except that Oracle will read multiple data blocks. Multi-block reads are typically used on full table scans. The name "scattered read" refers to the fact that multiple blocks are read into database block buffers that are 'scattered' throughout memory.
panels.title: db file scattered read - W_tm(s)

panels.description:
- gc cr request
- gc current block busy
- gc ...
panels.title: gc% event sum  - W_tm(s)

panels.description:
- enq: TX - row lock contention
- enq: TX - index contention
- enq: CF - contention
- enq: HW - contention
- enq: KO - fast object checkpoint
- enq: SQ - contention
- ...
panels.title: enq% event sum  - W_tm(s)

panels.description:
When a user session COMMITs (or rolls back), the sessions redo information needs to be flushed to the redo log file. 
The user session will post the LGWR to write all redo required from the log buffer to the redo log file. 
When the LGWR has finished it will post the user session. 
The user session waits on this wait event while waiting for LGWR to post it back to confirm all redo changes are safely on disk.

targets.expr:
rate(oracledb_ora_system_event_time_waited_micro{alias=~"$alias", name="log file sync"}[$intv]) /
rate(oracledb_ora_system_event_total_waits{alias=~"$alias", name="log file sync"}[$intv]) / 1000

rate(oracledb_ora_system_event_time_waited_micro{alias=~"$alias", name="log file sync"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv) /
rate(oracledb_ora_system_event_total_waits{alias=~"$alias", name="log file sync"}[$intv]  offset $diff_intv) / 1000
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: log file sync - Avg Wait time(ms)

panels.description: As the db file parallel write wait event belongs to the Oracle DBWR process, the log file parallel write wait event belongs to the Log Writer (LGWR) process. When it is time to write, the LGWR process writes the redo buffer to the online redo files in parallel and waits on the log file parallel write event until the last I/O is on disk.

targets.expr:
rate(oracledb_ora_system_event_time_waited_micro{alias=~"$alias", name="log file parallel write"}[$intv]) /
rate(oracledb_ora_system_event_total_waits{alias=~"$alias", name="log file parallel write"}[$intv]) / 1000

rate(oracledb_ora_system_event_time_waited_micro{alias=~"$alias", name="log file parallel write"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv) /
rate(oracledb_ora_system_event_total_waits{alias=~"$alias", name="log file parallel write"}[$intv]  offset $diff_intv) / 1000
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.description: This event shows a wait for a foreground process while doing a sequential read from the database. The I/O is generally issued as a single I/O request to the OS; the wait blocks until the I/O request completes.

panels.description:
Logical Reads  = DB Block Gets + Consistent Read Gets
This metric represents the number of logical reads per second.
A logical read is a read request for a data block from the SGA. 
Logical reads may result in a physical read if the requested block does not reside with the buffer cache.
panels.title: Logical Reads (blocks)

panels.description:
Logical Reads  = DB Block Gets + Consistent Read Gets
This metric represents the number of times per second a current block was requested.
panels.title: DB Block Gets (blocks)

panels.description:
Logical Reads  = DB Block Gets + Consistent Read Gets
This metric represents the number of times per second a consistent read was requested for a block.
panels.title: Consistent Read Gets (blocks)

panels.description: This metric represents the total number of changes per second that were part of an update or delete operation that were made to all blocks in the SGA.
panels.title: DB Block Changes (blocks)

panels.description: This metric represents the number of current blocks per second cloned to create consistent read (CR) blocks.
panels.title: CR Blocks Created (blocks)

panels.description: This metric represents the number of undo records applied for consistent read per second.

targets.expr: avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="CR Undo Records Applied Per Sec"}[$intv])

avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias",metric_name="CR Undo Records Applied Per Sec"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: CR Undo Records Applied (records)

panels.description:
This metric represents the number of data blocks read from disk per second.
When a user performs a SQL query, Oracle tries to retrieve the data from the database buffer cache (memory) first, then searches the disk if it is not already in memory.

panels.description: Tablespace Size

targets.expr:
sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_usage_tablespace_size{alias=~"$alias"}[24h])) without(__name__) * on (job, alias, tablespace_name )
sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_block_size{alias=~"$alias", contents=~"PERMANENT"}[24h])) without(__name__)

(sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_usage_tablespace_size{alias=~"$alias"}[24h])) without(__name__) - on (job, alias, tablespace_name )
 sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_usage_used_space{alias=~"$alias"}[24h])) without(__name__)
) * on (job, alias, tablespace_name )
sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_block_size{alias=~"$alias", contents=~"PERMANENT"}[24h])) without(__name__)

sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_usage_used_space{alias=~"$alias"}[24h])) without(__name__) * on (job, alias, tablespace_name )
sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_block_size{alias=~"$alias", contents=~"PERMANENT"}[24h])) without(__name__)

( sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_usage_used_space{alias=~"$alias"}[24h])) without(__name__) - on (job, alias, tablespace_name )
  sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_usage_used_space{alias=~"$alias"}[24h] offset 7d)) without(__name__))
* on (job, alias, tablespace_name )
sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_block_size{alias=~"$alias", contents=~"PERMANENT"}[24h])) without(__name__)

panels.title: Tablespace Size - Data Growth ( ~ 7 days )

panels.description: Tablespace Size

targets.expr:
sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_usage_tablespace_size{alias=~"$alias"}[24h])) without(__name__) * on (job, alias, tablespace_name )
sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_block_size{alias=~"$alias", contents!~"PERMANENT"}[24h])) without(__name__)

(sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_usage_tablespace_size{alias=~"$alias"}[24h])) without(__name__) - on (job, alias, tablespace_name )
 sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_usage_used_space{alias=~"$alias"}[24h])) without(__name__)
) * on (job, alias, tablespace_name )
sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_block_size{alias=~"$alias", contents!~"PERMANENT"}[24h])) without(__name__)

sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_usage_used_space{alias=~"$alias"}[24h])) without(__name__) * on (job, alias, tablespace_name )
sum(last_over_time(oracledb_tablespace_block_size{alias=~"$alias", contents!~"PERMANENT"}[24h])) without(__name__)

panels.title: Temporary, Undo Tablespace Size

panels.description:
This panel displays the most frequently waited tables and indexes based on data from Oracle Session samples.
It helps identify which database objects contribute the most to wait events, providing insights for performance tuning and optimization. Use this panel to monitor and analyze potential bottlenecks related to specific tables and indexes
panels.title: Top Waited Tables

panels.description:
This panel displays the most frequently waited tables and indexes based on data from Oracle Session samples.
It helps identify which database objects contribute the most to wait events, providing insights for performance tuning and optimization. Use this panel to monitor and analyze potential bottlenecks related to specific tables and indexes
panels.title: Top Waited Indexes

panels.description:
This metric represents the number of long table scans per second during sample period. 
A table is considered 'long' if the table is not cached and if its high-water mark is greater than 5 blocks.

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="Long Table Scans Per Sec"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: Long Table Scans

panels.description:
This metric represents the number of long and short table scans per second during the sample period. 
A table is considered 'long' if the table is not cached and if its high-water mark is greater than 5 blocks.

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="Total Table Scans Per Sec"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: Total Table Scans

panels.description: This metric represents the number of fast full index scans per second.

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="Full Index Scans Per Sec"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.description: This metric represents the total number of index scans per second.

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="Total Index Scans Per Sec"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: Total Index Scans

panels.description:
- This metric represents the data block buffer cache efficiency, as measured by the percentage of times the data block requested by the query is in memory.
- Effective use of the buffer cache can greatly reduce the I/O load on the database. If the buffer cache is too small, frequently accessed data will be flushed from the buffer cache too quickly which forces the information to be re-fetched from disk. Since disk access is much slower than memory access, application performance will suffer. In addition, the extra burden imposed on the I/O subsystem could introduce a bottleneck at one or more devices that would further degrade performance.
panels.title: Buffer Cache Hit (%)

panels.description: This metric represents the library cache efficiency, as measured by the percentage of times the fully parsed or compiled representation of PL/SQL blocks and SQL statements are already in memory.
panels.title: Library Cache Hit (%)

panels.description: This metric represents row  cache efficiency as measured by the percentage of requests against the data that were already in memory
panels.title: Row Cache Hit (%)

panels.description: This metric represents the total number of bytes processed in the PGA versus the total number of bytes processed plus extra bytes read/written in extra passes.
panels.title: PGA Cache Hit (%)

panels.description: This metric represents the sort efficiency as measured by the percentage of times sorts were performed in memory as opposed to going to disk.
panels.title: Memory Sorts (%)

panels.description: This metric represents the percentage of parse requests where the cursor was already in the cursor cache compared to the number of total parses.
panels.title: Soft Parse (%)

panels.description: This metric represents the current number of logons.
panels.title: Current Logons Count

panels.description:
This metric represents the current number of logons.
It indicates how often new sessions are being created in the database.
panels.title: Logons Per Sec

panels.description: Host user% + sys%
panels.title: Active Sessions

panels.description: This metric represents the number of logins, parses, or execute calls per second during the sample period.
panels.title: User Calls

panels.description: This metric represents the rate of SQL command executions per second.
panels.title: Executions

panels.description:
Sometimes, to execute a SQL statement issued by a user, the Oracle Server must issue additional statements. Such statements are called recursive calls or recursive SQL statements.
For example,
- When data dictionary information is not available in the data dictionary cache and must be retrieved from disk
- In the firing of database triggers
- In the execution of DDL statements
- In the execution of SQL statements within stored procedures, functions, packages and anonymous PL/SQL blocks
- In the enforcement of referential integrity constraints
panels.title: Recursive Calls

panels.description:
The total number of parses per second, both hard and soft. 
A hard parse occurs when a SQL statement has to be loaded into the shared pool. 
In this case, the Oracle Server has to allocate memory in the shared pool and parse the statement. 
A soft parse is recorded when the Oracle Server checks the shared pool for a SQL statement and finds a version of the statement that it can reuse.

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="Total Parse Count Per Sec"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: Total Parse Count

panels.description:
A hard parse occurs when a SQL statement has to be loaded into the shared pool. 
In this case, the Oracle Server has to allocate memory in the shared pool and parse the statement. 
A soft parse is recorded when the Oracle Server checks the shared pool for a SQL statement and finds a version of the statement that it can reuse.

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="Hard Parse Count Per Sec"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: Hard Parse Count

panels.description: This metric represents the total number of parse failures per second.

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias", metric_name="Parse Failure Count Per Sec"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: Parse Failure Count

panels.description: This metric represents the percentage of parse requests where the cursor was already in the cursor cache compared to the number of total parses.
panels.title: Soft Parse (%)

panels.description:
This metric represents the number of user commits performed, per second during the sample period. 
When a user commits a transaction, the redo generated that reflects the changes made to database blocks must be written to disk. 
Commits often represent the closest thing to a user transaction rate.
panels.title: User Commits

panels.description: This metric represents the number of times, per second during the sample period, that users manually issue the ROLLBACK statement or an error occurred during a user's transactions.
panels.title: User Rollbacks

panels.description: DB Time = CPU Time + Wait Time
panels.title: GC Wait Events ( Diff : $diff_intv )

panels.description:
- gc cr request
- gc current block busy
- gc ...

targets.expr:
sum(rate(oracledb_ora_system_event_time_waited_micro{alias=~"$alias", name=~"gc.*"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)) by (alias) /
sum(rate(oracledb_ora_system_event_total_waits{alias=~"$alias", name=~"gc.*"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)) by (alias) / 1000
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: gc% event sum  - Avg W_tm(ms)

panels.description: This metric represents the number of global cache blocks lost over the user-defined observation period.
panels.title: GC Blocks Lost

panels.description: This metric represents the number of blocks that encountered a corruption or checksum failure during interconnect over the user-defined observation period.
panels.title: GC Blocks Corrupted"

panels.description: the global cache consistent read blocks received.

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias",metric_name="GC CR Block Received Per Second"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: GC CR Received (blocks)

panels.description: This metric represents the average get time.

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias",metric_name="Global Cache Average CR Get Time"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv) * 10
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: GC CR Get Time (ms)

panels.description: the global cache current read blocks received.

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias",metric_name="GC Current Block Received Per Second"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: GC Current Received (blocks)

panels.description: This metric represents the average get time.

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(oracledb_ora_metric_value{alias=~"$alias",metric_name="Global Cache Average Current Get Time"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv) * 10
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: GC Current Get Time (ms)

list.description: group is defined in the Prometheus configuration file.
list.label: Group
list.name: group

list.label: interval
list.name: intv

previous days, You can input directly.
ex) 4d, 6w
